title: Authors and Citation
text: Kenny C, McCartan C (2025). adj: Lightweight Adjacency Lists. R package version 0.0.1, https://alarm-redist.org/adj/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {adj: Lightweight Adjacency Lists},   author = {Christopher T. Kenny and Cory McCartan},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.1},   url = {https://alarm-redist.org/adj/}, }

title: Lightweight Adjacency Lists
text: adj provides lightweight adjacency list class R, built vctrs package. Adjacency lists validated creation, automatically reindex subsetted indexed, support pretty-printing. Lists can easily converted zero-index basis, allows easy passing objects low-level languages processing. Creation adjacency lists shapefiles supported optional dependency geos.

title: Lightweight Adjacency Lists
text: can install development version adj GitHub :
code: # install.packages("pak") pak::pak("alarm-redist/adj")

title: Lightweight Adjacency Lists
text: adj comes loaded example data seven bridges Königsberg. can build adjacency graph using unique identifiers area. Alternatively, can create adjacency list list integers. , set duplicates = "remove" remove duplicate edges. created, adjacency lists can subsetted using standard R indexing, internal indices automatically updated. Quotient graphs can created adjacency lists grouping vector. , create quotient graph grouping two islands (areas D) together. Finally, adjacency lists can converted matrix zero-indexed.

title: adj: Lightweight Adjacency Lists — adj-package
text: Provides S3 class represent graph adjacency lists using 'vctrs'. Allows creation, subsetting, combining, pretty printing lists. Adjacency lists can easily converted zero-indexed lists, allows easy passing objects low-level languages processing.

title: adj: Lightweight Adjacency Lists — adj-package
text: Maintainer: Christopher T. Kenny ctkenny@proton.(ORCID) Authors: Cory McCartan mccartan@psu.edu (ORCID)

title: Internal vctrs methods — adj-vctrs
text: Internal vctrs methods

title: Create an adjacency list — adj
text: Create adjacency list list vectors adjacent node identifiers.

title: Create an adjacency list — adj
code: adj(   ...,   ids = NULL,   duplicates = c("warn", "error", "allow", "remove"),   self_loops = c("warn", "error", "allow", "remove") )  as_adj(x)  is_adj(x)  adj_to_list(x, ids = NULL)

title: Create an adjacency list — adj
text: ... Vectors single list vectors. Vectors comprised either (1-indexed) indices adjacent nodes, unique identifiers, must match provided ids. NULL can used place length-zero vector nodes without neighbors. ids vector unique node identifiers. provided vector ... matched identifiers. NULL, identifiers taken 1-indexed integers. duplicates Controls handling duplicate neighbors. value "warn" warns user; "error" throws error; "allow" allows duplicates, "remove" removes duplicates silently sets corresponding attribute "error". self_loops Controls handling self-loops (nodes adjacent ). value "warn" warns user; "error" throws error; "allow" allows self-loops, "remove" removes self-loops silently sets corresponding attribute "error". x adj list

title: Create an adjacency list — adj
text: adj list

title: Create an adjacency list — adj
text: Equality adj lists evaluated elementwise. Two sets neighbors considered equal contain neighbors, regardless order.

title: Create an adjacency list — adj
text: adj package focused graph operations. length() function return number nodes. compute number edges adjacency list , use sum(lengths()), divide 2 undirected graphs.

title: Create an adjacency list — adj
code: a1 = adj(list(c(2, 3), c(1, 3), c(1, 2))) a2 = adj(list(c(3, 2), c(3, 1), c(2, 1))) a1 == a2 #> [1] TRUE TRUE TRUE  adj(2:3, NULL, 4:5, integer(0), 1) #> <adj[5]> #> [1] {2, 3} {}     {4, 5} {}     {1}    adj(1, 2, 3, self_loops = "remove") #> <adj[3]> #> [1] {} {} {}  adj(konigsberg$bridge_to, ids = konigsberg$area, duplicates = "allow") #> <adj[4]> #> [1] {2, 2, 3, …} {1, 1, 4}    {1, 1, 4}    {1, 2, 3}    adj(konigsberg$bridge_to, ids = konigsberg$area, duplicates = "remove") #> <adj[4]> #> [1] {2, 3, 4} {1, 4}    {1, 4}    {1, 2, 3}

what: Find a coloring of an adjacency list — adj_color
title: Find a coloring of an adjacency list — adj_color
text: Greedily finds coloring adjacency list, optionally grouped provied vector.

title: Find a coloring of an adjacency list — adj_color
code: adj_color(x, groups = NULL, colors = 0, method = c("dsatur", "greedy"))

title: Find a coloring of an adjacency list — adj_color
text: x adj list groups optional vector specifying group membership node x. colors Number colors use. 0 (default), uses colors possible greedy algorithm. method Coloring method use. "dsatur" uses DSatur algorithm try minimize number colors. "greedy" traverses nodes decreasing order degree may appropriate colors desired.

title: Find a coloring of an adjacency list — adj_color
text: integer vector

title: Find a coloring of an adjacency list — adj_color
text: Brélaz, Daniel (1979-04-01). "New methods color vertices graph". Communications ACM. 22 (4): 251–256.

title: Find a coloring of an adjacency list — adj_color
code: a <- adj(konigsberg$bridge_to, ids = konigsberg$area, duplicates = "allow") adj_color(a) #> [1] 1 2 2 3 adj_color(a, colors = 3) #> [1] 1 2 2 3 adj_color(a, groups = c("AD", "BC", "BC", "AD")) #> [1] 1 2 2 1

what: Add and subtract edges from an adjacency list — adj_edges
title: Add and subtract edges from an adjacency list — adj_edges
text: Add subtract edges adjacency list

title: Add and subtract edges from an adjacency list — adj_edges
code: adj_add_edges(x, v1, v2, ids = NULL)  adj_subtract_edges(x, v1, v2, ids = NULL)

title: Add and subtract edges from an adjacency list — adj_edges
text: x adj list object coercible adj list v1 vector vertex identifiers first vertex. Can integer index value look ids, argument provided. one identifier present, connects corresponding entry v2. v2 vector vertex identifiers second vertex. Can integer index value look ids, argument provided. one identifier present, connects corresponding entry v1. ids vector unique node identifiers. provided vector v1 v2 matched identifiers. NULL, identifiers taken 1-indexed integers.

title: Add and subtract edges from an adjacency list — adj_edges
text: adj list

title: Add and subtract edges from an adjacency list — adj_edges
code: a <- adj(c(2, 3), 1, 1) adj_add_edges(a, 2, 3) adj_subtract_edges(a, 1, 2) #> <adj[3]> #> [1] {3} {}  {1}

what: Convert adjacency lists to and from adjacency matrices — adj_from_matrix
title: Convert adjacency lists to and from adjacency matrices — adj_from_matrix
text: Adjacency lists can converted adjacency matrices vice versa without loss.

title: Convert adjacency lists to and from adjacency matrices — adj_from_matrix
code: adj_from_matrix(   x,   duplicates = c("warn", "error", "allow", "remove"),   self_loops = c("warn", "error", "allow", "remove") )  # S3 method for class 'adj' as.matrix(x, ...)

title: Convert adjacency lists to and from adjacency matrices — adj_from_matrix
text: x adjacency list matrix duplicates Controls handling duplicate neighbors. value "warn" warns user; "error" throws error; "allow" allows duplicates, "remove" removes duplicates silently sets corresponding attribute "error". self_loops Controls handling self-loops (nodes adjacent ). value "warn" warns user; "error" throws error; "allow" allows self-loops, "remove" removes self-loops silently sets corresponding attribute "error". ... Ignored.

title: Convert adjacency lists to and from adjacency matrices — adj_from_matrix
text: adj_from_matrix() returns adj list; .matrix() returns matrix.

title: Convert adjacency lists to and from adjacency matrices — adj_from_matrix
code: adj_from_matrix(1 - diag(3)) #> <adj[3]> #> [1] {2, 3} {1, 3} {1, 2}  a = adj(konigsberg$bridge_to, ids = konigsberg$area, duplicates = "allow") mat = as.matrix(a) all(a == adj_from_matrix(mat, duplicates = "allow")) # TRUE #> [1] TRUE

code: adj_from_shp(shp)

title: Create an adj list from a set of spatial polygons — adj_from_shp
text: shp object convertible geos geometries representing polygons, sf object, well-known text strings, geos geometries.

title: Create an adj list from a set of spatial polygons — adj_from_shp
text: adj list

title: Create an adj list from a set of spatial polygons — adj_from_shp

what: Indexing operations on adjacency lists — adj_indexing
title: Indexing operations on adjacency lists — adj_indexing
text: adj overrides default [ c() methods allow filtering, reordering, concatenating adjacency lists ensuring indices remain internally consistent.

title: Indexing operations on adjacency lists — adj_indexing
code: # S3 method for class 'adj' x[i, ...]  # S3 method for class 'adj' c(...)

title: Indexing operations on adjacency lists — adj_indexing
text: x adjacency list class adj Indexing vector ... c(), adjacency lists concatenate. Ignored [.

title: Indexing operations on adjacency lists — adj_indexing
code: a <- adj(c(2, 3), c(1, 3), c(1, 2)) a[1:2] #> <adj[2]> #> [1] {2} {1} all(sample(a) == a) # any permutation yields the same graph #> [1] TRUE  a <- adj(konigsberg$bridge_to, ids = konigsberg$area, duplicates = "remove") c(a, a) # concatenates graphs with no connecting edges #> <adj[8]> #> [1] {2, 3, 4} {1, 4}    {1, 4}    {1, 2, 3} {6, 7, 8} {5, 8}    {5, 8}    #> [8] {5, 6, 7}

what: Quotient an adjacency list by a vector — adj_quotient
title: Quotient an adjacency list by a vector — adj_quotient
text: Computes quotient graph given adjacency list provided grouping vector. Nodes groups merged single nodes quotient graph. resulting multi-edges self-loops handled according specified parameters.

title: Quotient an adjacency list by a vector — adj_quotient
code: adj_quotient(   x,   groups,   duplicates = c("remove", "allow", "error", "warn"),   self_loops = c("remove", "allow", "error", "warn") )  adj_quotient_int(   x,   groups,   n_groups,   duplicates = c("remove", "allow", "error", "warn"),   self_loops = c("remove", "allow", "error", "warn") )

title: Quotient an adjacency list by a vector — adj_quotient
text: x adj list groups vector specifying group membership node x. adj_quotient() process vector vctrs::vec_group_id(); adj_quotient_int() expects (1-indexed) integer vector. duplicates Controls handling duplicate neighbors. value "warn" warns user; "error" throws error; "allow" allows duplicates, "remove" removes duplicates silently sets corresponding attribute "error". self_loops Controls handling self-loops (nodes adjacent ). value "warn" warns user; "error" throws error; "allow" allows self-loops, "remove" removes self-loops silently sets corresponding attribute "error". n_groups Number unique groups.

title: Quotient an adjacency list by a vector — adj_quotient
text: new adj list.

title: Quotient an adjacency list by a vector — adj_quotient
code: a <- adj(konigsberg$bridge_to, ids = konigsberg$area, duplicates = "allow") # merge two islands (A and D) adj_quotient(a, c("AD", "B", "C", "AD")) #> <adj[3]> #> [1] {2, 3} {1}    {1}    adj_quotient_int(a, c(1L, 2L, 3L, 1L), n_group = 3L, self_loops = "allow") #> <adj[3]> #> [1] {2, 3, 1} {1}       {1}

what: Convert adjacency list to use zero-based indices — adj_zero_index
title: Convert adjacency list to use zero-based indices — adj_zero_index
text: Subtracts 1 index adjacency list returns bare list integer vectors, suitable providing C/C++ code uses zero-based indexing.

title: Convert adjacency list to use zero-based indices — adj_zero_index
code: adj_zero_index(x)

title: Convert adjacency list to use zero-based indices — adj_zero_index
text: x adjacency list.

title: Convert adjacency list to use zero-based indices — adj_zero_index
text: list integer vectors zero-based indices.

title: Convert adjacency list to use zero-based indices — adj_zero_index
code: a <- adj(konigsberg$bridge_to, ids = konigsberg$area, duplicates = "allow") adj_zero_index(a) #> [[1]] #> [1] 1 1 2 2 3 #>  #> [[2]] #> [1] 0 0 3 #>  #> [[3]] #> [1] 0 0 3 #>  #> [[4]] #> [1] 0 1 2 #>

text: x adj list. n Maximum number neighbors show truncating ellipsis. ... Ignored.

title: Format and print methods for adjacency lists — format.adj
text: character vector representing entry adjacency list.

title: Format and print methods for adjacency lists — format.adj
code: a = adj(konigsberg$bridge_to, ids = konigsberg$area, duplicates = "allow") format(a) #> [1] "{2, 2, 3, …}" "{1, 1, 4}"    "{1, 1, 4}"    "{1, 2, 3}"    print(a, n = 5) #> <adj[4]> #> [1] {2, 2, 3, 3, 4} {1, 1, 4}       {1, 1, 4}       {1, 2, 3}

what: The Seven Bridges of Königsberg — konigsberg
title: The Seven Bridges of Königsberg — konigsberg
text: dataset encoding adjacency structure seven bridges Königsberg, Prussia, described Leonhard Euler 1736.

title: The Seven Bridges of Königsberg — konigsberg
code: konigsberg

title: The Seven Bridges of Königsberg — konigsberg
text: data frame 4 rows 4 columns: area four land areas, -D, described Euler. Area '' corresponds central island Kneiphof. bridge_to list column, entry character vector listing areas directly connected bridges area row. x longitude area center, plotting. y latitude area center, plotting.

title: The Seven Bridges of Königsberg — konigsberg
text: Euler, Leonhard (1741). "Solutio problematis ad geometriam situs pertinentis". Commentarii Academiae Scientiarum Petropolitanae: 128–140.

what: Basic plotting for adjacency lists — plot.adj
title: Basic plotting for adjacency lists — plot.adj
text: Plots adjacency list set nodes edges, optional coordinate values node. Edge thickness proportional number edges pair nodes. Self loops represented larger points.

title: Basic plotting for adjacency lists — plot.adj
code: # S3 method for class 'adj' plot(x, y = NULL, edges = NULL, nodes = TRUE, xlab = NA, ylab = NA, ...)

title: Basic plotting for adjacency lists — plot.adj
text: x adj list y Optional matrix coordinates node. NULL, nodes plotted along diagonal. types accepted long convertible 2-column matrix .matrix(y)[, 1:2], run internally. edges Type line use drawing edges. Passed graphics::lines(). y NULL, defaults "s" (step function); otherwise defaults "l" straight line. nodes TRUE, nodes plotted points; FALSE, edges plotted. xlab, ylab Labels x- y-axes. ... Additional arguments passed initial plot() nodes.

title: Basic plotting for adjacency lists — plot.adj
text: NULL, invisibly.

title: Basic plotting for adjacency lists — plot.adj
code: plot(adj(2, c(1, 3), 2))  plot(adj(2, c(1, 2, 3), c(2, 2, 2), self_loops="allow", duplicates="allow"))   a <- adj(konigsberg$bridge_to, ids = konigsberg$area, duplicates = "allow") plot(a, konigsberg[c("x", "y")])
